key_points: Jacob Chansley, known as the 'QAnon shaman', was sentenced to 41 months in prison for his role in the Jan. 6 Capitol riot.
Judge Royce Lamberth found Chansley's remorse genuine but emphasized the seriousness of his actions.
Chansley's sentence is on the lower end of the federal guidelines but ties for the longest among Capitol riot defendants who have pleaded guilty.
He pleaded guilty to a single count of obstructing a proceeding of Congress.
Chansley will receive credit for time served since his arrest in January.
Prosecutors highlighted Chansley's early and prominent participation in the riot and sought a 51-month sentence.
During the sentencing hearing, a video was presented showing Chansley howling inside Congress, which the prosecution described as 'chilling'.
Chansley's defense argued for a lighter sentence citing his remorse and mental health issues.
In his address to the court, Chansley cited various figures and works as lessons for his repentance but stressed he is not a violent man or a domestic terrorist.
His conduct was criticized for undermining the peaceful transfer of presidential power.
